question: why do more men commit crimes than women

clueweb22-en0042-88-09835.point_content: A lower resting heart rate partially explains why men commit more crime than women.
spans: A lower resting heart rate partially explains why men commit more crime than women, according to a new study led by researchers at the University of Pennsylvania.

clueweb22-en0042-88-09835.point_content: Men are more likely to commit crime than women, with 93.3 percent of federal inmates being men as of February 2017.
spans: Research over time has consistently shown that men are more likely to commit crime than women. As of February 2017, 93.3 percent of federal inmates were men, according to the Federal Bureau of Prisons.

clueweb22-en0042-88-09835.point_content: Girls had higher resting heart rates at age 11 compared to boys, and by age 23, men had committed a larger number of crimes than women.
spans: Girls had higher resting heart rates at age 11 compared to boys. By age 23, men had committed a larger number of crimes than women.

clueweb22-en0042-88-09835.point_content: Adults who committed drug offenses or serious violent crimes by age 23 had lower average resting heart rates at age 11 than those who did not commit such crimes.
spans: Adults of either gender who had committed drug offenses by the age of 23 had an average resting heart rate of 86.02 beats per minute at age 11. In comparison, adults of both genders who had not committed a drug offense by age 23 had an average resting heart rate of 93.64 beats per minute at age 11.

Adults who had committed serious violent crimes by the age of 23 had an average resting heart rate of 85.22 beats per minute at age 11, regardless of gender. On the other hand, adults who had not committed a serious violent crime by age 23 had an average resting heart rate of 93.89 beats per minute at age 11.

clueweb22-en0042-88-09835.point_content: A low heart rate explains some of the link between gender and crime, partly explaining higher levels of offending in males.
spans: A low heart rate explains some of the link between gender and crime. “Although ﬁndings do not document causality and do not suggest that a low heart rate completely accounts for the gender gap, they are, to our knowledge, the ﬁrst to show that lower heart rates in males partly explain their higher levels of offending.”

clueweb22-en0015-67-12375.point_content: Men are far more likely to express their aggression directly: through physical violence or verbal abuse, which is a form that is criminalized.
spans: Men are far more likely to express their aggression directly: through physical violence or verbal abuse.

clueweb22-en0015-67-12375.point_content: Testosterone spikes in competitive situations among men with a history of violence can result in violence, but this effect is not consistent across all men.
spans: Testosterone spikes when men are in competitive or challenging situations with other men, however only among men with a history of violence do we see this boost in hormones result in violence.
the effect of a testosterone boost is not consistent across the male population

clueweb22-en0015-67-12375.point_content: Certain patterns of male violence are strongly correlated with a belief in strict gender roles and traditional masculinity ideology.
spans: certain patterns of male violence — particularly against women and gender non-conforming men — are strongly correlated with a belief in strict gender roles.
traditional masculinity ideology

spans: men three times more likely to have the disorder than women
ASPD which is defined by a pervasive and persistent disregard for morals, social norms and the rights and feelings of others

clueweb22-en0030-81-04856.point_content: Men might commit more crime than women because they believe that they need to be financially successful to prove they are a ‘real man’.
spans: Men might commit more crime than women because they believe that they need to be financially successful to prove they are a ‘real man’.

clueweb22-en0030-81-04856.point_content: Some men turn to crime to achieve financial success when legitimate means are unavailable, such as dealing drugs or theft, which are mainly male pursuits.
spans: some will turn to crime in order ‘show they are successful’
earning money by criminal means – by dealing drugs or doing ‘moped thefts’ for example – all of which seem to be mainly male pursuits.

clueweb22-en0030-81-04856.point_content: Men with low status may prove their status and toughness through violence, as found with mainly working class men in Newcastle.
spans: seek to prove their status and toughness through violence, as Winlow found with mainly working class men in Newcastle.

clueweb22-en0030-81-04856.point_content: Highly paid men may commit white collar crimes like fraud to make more money and prove status.
spans: within companies some highly paid men turn to fraud to make even more money than their male peers.

clueweb22-en0030-81-04856.point_content: Men might commit more crime than women to ‘prove they are in control of women’, which explains domestic violence across all class groups.
spans: Men might commit more crime than women to ‘prove they are in control of women’.
this is largely what explains domestic violence which happens across all class groups.

clueweb22-en0030-81-04856.point_content: Domestic violence and harassment are criminal ways men express control over women, perpetuated by patriarchal control and media objectification.
spans: DV is just one criminal way men express control in in private – it also happens in public through ‘harrassment’ on the streets
‘the male gaze’ and the objectification of women in the media, especially porn, all of which are interwoven in a network of patriarchal control over women.

clueweb22-en0030-81-04856.point_content: Men also use sexual violence to control other men, such as male rape in conflict and prisons as a means to express power.
spans: men don’t necessarily just use sexual violence to control women, they also use it to control other men – male rape has been used against captured combatants in the DRC for example, and it can also be used in prisons where ‘situational homosexuality’ can be used as a means some men use to express their power over others.

clueweb22-en0001-89-04331.point_content: Men are more likely to commit crime than women, as shown by research and prison statistics.
spans: Research over time has consistently shown that men are more likely to commit crime than women.

As of February 2017, 93.3 percent of federal inmates were men, according to the Federal Bureau of Prisons. A 2015 report from the U.S. Department of Justice suggests the vast majority of state prisoners also are men.

clueweb22-en0001-89-04331.point_content: A lower resting heart rate partially explains why men commit more crime than women.
spans: A lower resting heart rate partially explains why men commit more crime than women, according to a new study led by researchers at the University of Pennsylvania.

clueweb22-en0001-89-04331.point_content: Girls had higher resting heart rates at age 11 compared to boys, and men committed more crimes by age 23.
spans: Girls had higher resting heart rates at age 11 compared to boys.
By age 23, men had committed a larger number of crimes than women.

clueweb22-en0001-89-04331.point_content: Adults who committed drug offenses or serious violent crimes had lower resting heart rates at age 11 than those who did not commit such crimes.
spans: Adults of either gender who had committed drug offenses by the age of 23 had an average resting heart rate of 86.02 beats per minute at age 11.
In comparison, adults of both genders who had not committed a drug offense by age 23 had an average resting heart rate of 93.64 beats per minute at age 11.
Adults who had committed serious violent crimes by the age of 23 had an average resting heart rate of 85.22 beats per minute at age 11, regardless of gender.
On the other hand, adults who had not committed a serious violent crime by age 23 had an average resting heart rate of 93.89 beats per minute at age 11.

clueweb22-en0001-89-04331.point_content: Lower heart rates in males partly explain their higher levels of offending, though it does not completely account for the gender gap in crime.
spans: A low heart rate explains some of the link between gender and crime.

Although ﬁndings do not document causality and do not suggest that a low heart rate completely accounts for the gender gap, they are, to our knowledge, the ﬁrst to show that lower heart rates in males partly explain their higher levels of offending.

clueweb22-en0013-71-13689.point_content: Men commit an overwhelming majority of all crimes and acts of violence in every single human society without exception.
spans: In every single human society without an exception, men commit an overwhelming majority of all crimes and acts of violence.

clueweb22-en0013-71-13689.point_content: Men are more criminal and violent than women due to universal human nature reflected in cultural universals.
spans: And among the many cultural universals is the fact that men in every society are so much more criminal and violent than women.

clueweb22-en0013-71-13689.point_content: Evolutionary history of polygyny leads to high male competition and violence for reproductive access.
spans: humans throughout their evolutionary history were effectively polygynous, and many married men had multiple wives.

In a polygynous society, some males monopolize reproductive access to all females while other males are left out; in such a society, some males do not get to reproduce at all, while almost all females do.
This large sex difference in fitness variance makes males highly competitive in their effort not to be left out of the reproductive game altogether.
This competition among men leads to a high level of violence (murder, assault, and battery) among them.

clueweb22-en0013-71-13689.point_content: Most homicides between men originate from trivial altercations related to honor, status, and reputation, which are linked to reproductive success.
spans: most homicides between men originate from what is known as “trivial altercations.”
a fight about trivial matters of honor, status, and reputation between men (such as when one man insults another or makes moves on another’s girlfriend).

Because women prefer to mate with men of high status and good reputation, a man’s status and reputation directly correlates with his reproductive success; the higher the status and the better the reputation of the man, the more reproductively successful he is.
Men are therefore highly motivated (albeit unconsciously) to protect their honor, and often go to extreme lengths to do so.

clueweb22-en0013-71-13689.point_content: Rape by men of lower status may be motivated by psychological mechanisms to gain reproductive access illegitimately when legitimate means are unavailable.
spans: Predatory rapists are overwhelmingly men of lower class and status, who have very dim prospects of gaining legitimate reproductive access to women.
rape may be motivated by men’s psychological mechanisms that urge them to gain reproductive access to women illegitimately when they do not have the legitimate means to do so.

clueweb22-en0007-05-04074.point_content: There are approximately equal numbers of men and women in the population as a whole, but 85% of people arrested are male, around 75% of those prosecuted are male and 95% of people who go to prison are male.
spans: There are approximately equal numbers of men and women in the population as a whole, but 85% of people arrested are male, around 75% of those prosecuted are male and 95% of people who go to prison are male

clueweb22-en0007-05-04074.point_content: Women commit less crime than men, and less serious crimes than men.
spans: The figures show that women commit less crime than men, and less serious crimes than men.

clueweb22-en0007-05-04074.point_content: Men are twice as likely to be on trial for an indictable offence compared to women.
spans: Men are twice as likely to be on trial for an indictable offence compared to women.

clueweb22-en0007-05-04074.point_content: For the more serious, indictable offences such as violence and robbery, men commit around 85-90% of these, but for sexual offenses 98% of offenders are men, only 2% are women.
spans: for the more serious, indictable offences such as violence and robbery, men commit around 85-90% of these, but for sexual offenses 98% of offenders are men, only 2% are women.

spans: Testosterone spikes when men are in competitive or challenging situations with other men, however only among men with a history of violence do we see this boost in hormones result in violence.

clueweb22-en0023-07-17606.point_content: Certain patterns of male violence are strongly correlated with a belief in strict gender roles and traditional masculinity ideology.
spans: certain patterns of male violence — particularly against women and gender nonconforming men — are strongly correlated with a belief in strict gender roles.
The American Psychological Association recently issued guidelines that caution against the impact of “traditional masculinity ideology” on mental wellbeing.

clueweb22-en0023-07-17606.point_content: Some men, because of their limited view of masculinity, are far more likely to act violently towards the vulnerable and to fail to seek help when they need it.
spans: some men, because of their limited view of masculinity, are far more likely to act violently towards the vulnerable and to fail to seek help when they need it.

spans: In general, females appear to be substantially underrepresented throughout the CJS compared with males.

clueweb22-en0009-98-15938.point_content: The majority (85%) of arrests continue to be accounted for by males in 2019/20.
spans: The majority (85%) of arrests continue to be accounted for by males in 2019/20.

clueweb22-en0009-98-15938.point_content: In 2019, 74% of individuals dealt with by the Criminal Justice System were male, and 26% were female.
spans: In 2019, 74% of individuals dealt with by the Criminal Justice System were male, and 26% were female.

clueweb22-en0009-98-15938.point_content: Females were typically dealt with for less severe offences at court.
spans: Females were typically dealt with for less severe offences at court.

clueweb22-en0009-98-15938.point_content: In 2019, the average custodial sentence length (ACSL) for male offenders was 19.7 months compared to 11.3 months for female offenders.
spans: In 2019, the average custodial sentence length (ACSL) for male offenders was 19.7 months compared to 11.3 months for female offenders.

clueweb22-en0009-98-15938.point_content: The majority (95%) of the prison population were male.
spans: The majority (95%) of the prison population were male.

spans: Males were serving longer custodial sentence lengths.

spans: In 2019, Black males were particularly over represented, accounting for 12% of all male prosecutions. This compared to Black females accounting for 6% of all female prosecutions.

clueweb22-en0009-98-15938.point_content: A higher proportion of female offenders were first time offenders, compared to males.
spans: A higher proportion of female offenders were first time offenders, compared to males.

clueweb22-en0009-98-15938.point_content: In the 2017/18 cohort, the reoffending rate was higher for males at 30%, compared to 23% for females.
spans: In the 2017/18 cohort, the reoffending rate was higher for males at 30%, compared to 23% for females.

clueweb22-en0009-98-15938.point_content: Females had a higher average number of reoffences per reoffender compared to males, at 4.33 and 3.99, respectively.
spans: Females had a higher average number of reoffences per reoffender compared to males, at 4.33 and 3.99, respectively.

clueweb22-en0009-98-15938.point_content: TV licence evasion was the most common offence for which females were convicted in 2019.
spans: TV licence evasion was the most common offence for which females were convicted in 2019.

clueweb22-en0009-98-15938.point_content: The custody rate for theft from shops was lower for female offenders (19%) than for males (26%).
spans: The custody rate for this offence was lower for female offenders (19%) than for males (26%).

clueweb22-en0009-98-15938.point_content: A consistently larger proportion of male offenders receive custodial sentences whereas larger proportions of female offenders receive community sentences or a conditional discharge.
spans: When comparing sentencing outcomes for male and female offenders, a consistently larger proportion of male offenders receive custodial sentences whereas larger proportions of female offenders receive community sentences or a conditional discharge.

clueweb22-en0036-23-02701.point_content: Men are much more likely to commit crimes than women (although female crime has been rising faster than male crime since the late 20th century).
spans: Men are much more likely to commit crimes than women (although female crime has been rising faster than male crime since the late 20th century).

clueweb22-en0036-23-02701.point_content: Men and women also appear to commit different types of crimes (men are much more likely to commit violent crimes, for instance, accounting for 90% of murderers).
spans: Men and women also appear to commit different types of crimes (men are much more likely to commit violent crimes, for instance, accounting for 90% of murderers).

clueweb22-en0036-23-02701.point_content: One explanation for gender differences in levels of criminality is that men and women are simply different, with "normal" masculinity far more open to criminality than "normal" femininity.
spans: One explanation for gender differences in levels of criminality is that men and women are simply different.
the suggestion is that "normal" masculinity is far more open to criminality than "normal" femininity.

clueweb22-en0036-23-02701.point_content: Socialisation to be tough, dominant, etc. is more prone to criminality than socialisation to be nurturing and compliant.
spans: Socialisation to be tough, dominant, etc. is more prone to criminality than socialisation to be nurturing and compliant.

clueweb22-en0036-23-02701.point_content: Marginalisation means women have fewer opportunities to commit crimes because of their marginal position in a patriarchal society, unlike men who have greater opportunity to form criminal subcultures and commit occupational crime.
spans: Marginalisation: some feminist sociologists suggest that the marginal position of women in a patriarchal society means that they commit fewer crimes than men.

They have fewer opportunities to commit crimes because of marginalisation, as opposed to men who can commit occupational crime as well as their having a greater opportunity to form criminal subcultures because they are not confined to a domestic role.

clueweb22-en0036-23-02701.point_content: Women and girls are controlled more than boys and men, which limits their opportunities for criminality.
spans: Another explanation for gender differences in criminality is the idea that women and girls are controlled more than boys and men are.
According to Frances Heidensohn, girls are controlled by fathers and other relatives until they are married when they are controlled by their husbands.
The fact that boys and young men spend more time away from older or otherwise authoritative figures could account for their higher levels of criminality, especially anti–social behaviour.

clueweb22-en0036-23-02701.point_content: The chivalry thesis suggests male law enforcement officers protect women from the criminal justice system, leading to fewer recorded crimes by women.
spans: some sociologists suggest that these statistics do not reflect reality.
mostly male law enforcement officers tend to attempt to protect women from the criminal justice system out of gentlemanliness.
This is known as the chivalry thesis .

clueweb22-en0036-23-02701.point_content: Judges and magistrates may take pleas for mitigation for women more seriously due to social expectations and chivalric values.
spans: In terms of punishment, judges and magistrates (again predominantly male) may take pleas for mitigation more seriously.

clueweb22-en0017-24-00571.point_content: Men have always had a reputation for being more inclined to criminal behaviour than women, especially when it comes to committing violent offences such as assault or murder.
spans: Men have always had a reputation for being more inclined to criminal behaviour than women, especially when it comes to committing violent offences such as assault or murder.

clueweb22-en0017-24-00571.point_content: Only one fifth of NSW offenders in 2011-2012 being female, suggesting men commit more crimes.
spans: only one fifth of NSW offenders in 2011-2012 being female

clueweb22-en0017-24-00571.point_content: Women commit fewer serious crimes than men, and/or receive custodial sentences less frequently, as only 7% of inmates are female.
spans: Currently in NSW jails, only 7% of the inmates are female, which would suggest that women commit fewer serious crimes than men, and/or that they receive custodial sentences less frequently.

clueweb22-en0017-24-00571.point_content: Women have a lower rate of repeat prison sentences and receive shorter sentences than men.
spans: Women have a lower rate of repeat prison sentences at 37.7%, compared to male offenders whose recidivism rate is 52.8%.
Women also received shorter sentences on the whole, with the average for adult female prisoners in 2012 at just over two years, while for adult males the average sentence length was almost 40 months.

clueweb22-en0017-24-00571.point_content: Men are more frequently found guilty of domestic violence assault, non-domestic violence assault, property damage, and drug offences as well as offensive behaviour.
spans: male offenders, who were more frequently found guilty of domestic violence assault, non-domestic violence assault, property damage, and drug offences as well as offensive behaviour.

clueweb22-en0017-24-00571.point_content: The vast majority of assault offences are still committed by men, at four times the number of assault offences committed by women.

clueweb22-en0017-24-00571.point_content: Men are most commonly associated with violent and sexual crimes and the rate of these types of crimes committed by men is significantly higher than those committed by women.

clueweb22-en0021-60-15525.point_content: Women are more likely than men to be in prison for fraud and robbery, while men are more apt to have committed violent crimes.
spans: Women are more likely than men to be in prison for fraud and robbery, while men are more apt to have committed violent crimes.

clueweb22-en0021-60-15525.point_content: Almost one-third of all female prisoners are behind bars on property charges vs 18 percent of male prisoners.

clueweb22-en0021-60-15525.point_content: Men were more likely to have been locked up for murder, rape or sexual assault.
spans: Men, meanwhile, were more likely to have been locked up for murder, rape or sexual assault.
